title: General Wave Properties: Advanced Applications (Including Sound)
subject: Physics

questions.question: A water wave travels 90 m in 15 seconds. If 15 complete waves pass a point in this time, what is the wavelength?
questions.explanation: Wave speed v = 90 / 15 = 6 m/s. Frequency f = 15 / 15 = 1 Hz. λ = v / f = 6 / 1 = 6 m.

questions.question: Which frequency is within the typical human audible range?
questions.explanation: The human audible range is approximately 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. 15,000 Hz is within this range.

questions.question: What determines the pitch of a sound?
questions.explanation: Pitch is determined by frequency: higher frequency → higher pitch. Loudness is determined by amplitude.

questions.question: In which medium does sound travel fastest?
questions.explanation: Sound travels fastest in solids (e.g., steel ≈ 5000 m/s), slower in liquids (water ≈ 1500 m/s), slowest in gases (air ≈ 340 m/s). Sound cannot travel in vacuum.

questions.question: A student shouts towards a cliff 170 m away. How long after shouting will the echo be heard? (Speed of sound = 340 m/s)
questions.explanation: Total distance = to cliff and back = 2 × 170 = 340 m. Time = distance / speed = 340 / 340 = 1.0 s.

questions.question: Two sounds have the same pitch but different loudness. What must be true?
options: They have the same frequency but different amplitudes
They have the same amplitude but different frequencies
They have different wavelengths and speeds
They are produced by different sources only
questions.explanation: Same pitch → same frequency. Different loudness → different amplitudes. Speed and wavelength may be the same if in the same medium.

questions.question: A sound wave has a frequency of 500 Hz and a wavelength of 0.68 m in air. What is its speed?
Why can't sound travel in space?
options: Sound requires a medium to propagate, and space is a vacuum
Sound waves are too weak in space
Space is too cold for sound
questions.explanation: Sound is a mechanical wave and requires particles to vibrate. Space is mostly vacuum — no medium → no sound propagation.

questions.question: An echo is heard 3.0 seconds after a shout. How far is the reflecting surface? (Speed of sound = 340 m/s)
questions.explanation: Total distance = v × t = 340 × 3 = 1020 m. Distance to surface = 1020 / 2 = 510 m.

questions.question: Which application uses the reflection of sound waves?
questions.explanation: Sonar (sound navigation and ranging) uses echo reflection to detect underwater objects or measure depth.

questions.question: A wave has a period of 0.004 s. Is it audible to humans?
options: Yes, because its frequency is 250 Hz
Yes, because it's a sound wave
questions.explanation: f = 1/T = 1/0.004 = 250 Hz. Since 20 Hz < 250 Hz < 20,000 Hz, it is audible.

questions.question: When sound travels from air into water, what happens to its speed and wavelength?
questions.explanation: Speed of sound in water (~1500 m/s) > air (~340 m/s). Frequency unchanged, so λ = v/f also increases.

questions.question: Which statement about wave energy is correct?
options: Waves transfer energy without transferring matter
Matter moves with the wave over long distances
Energy is only transferred in transverse waves
Amplitude has no effect on energy
questions.explanation: Waves transfer energy through oscillations, but there is no net movement of matter (e.g., a floating object bobs in place).

questions.question: The graph shows displacement vs. time for a wave with a period of 0.05 s. What is the frequency?
A sound wave has a wavelength of 1.7 m in air (speed = 340 m/s). What is its period?
Which best describes a longitudinal wave?
options: Particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave travel
Particles vibrate perpendicular to wave travel
It includes light and radio waves
questions.explanation: In longitudinal waves (e.g., sound), particles oscillate parallel to the direction of propagation. Transverse waves (e.g., light) oscillate perpendicularly.

questions.question: If the amplitude of a sound wave increases, what happens to its loudness and pitch?
questions.explanation: Loudness depends on amplitude; pitch depends on frequency. Changing amplitude affects loudness only.

questions.question: A dolphin uses sound waves to locate fish 75 m away. If the speed of sound in water is 1500 m/s, how long does it take for the echo to return?
questions.explanation: Total distance = 2 × 75 = 150 m. Time = 150 / 1500 = 0.1 s.

questions.question: Which frequency would be classified as infrasound?
questions.explanation: Infrasound is below 20 Hz. Ultrasound is above 20,000 Hz. 10 Hz is infrasound.
